descriptions.content: The dative is used to indicate the grammatical role of goal, i.e., the person or thing to which the action is directed, or the owner of something in possessive constructions. This particle corresponds to English “to,” or else is not translated at all. It is also used to form adverbs.

The dative is used to indicate the grammatical role of goal, i.e., the person or thing to which the action is directed, or the owner of something in possessive constructions. This particle corresponds to English “to,” or else is not translated at all. It is also used to form adverbs.

  • ཁོང་གིས་བློ་བཟང་ལ་ཡི་གེ་བཏང་སོང་། “He sent a letter to Lopzang.”
  • ཁོང་ལ་དངུལ་ཡོད་རེད། “He has money.”
  • གསལ་པོ་ “Clear” with the addition of the dative becomes གསལ་པོར་ “clearly”

As in the above example, possessive constructions in Tibetan are formed with the dative:

  • Subject (dative) + Object (absolutive) + Verb.

This structure follows the pattern “to X there is Y,” and may be translated literally as “to him there is money.” It has exactly the same form as constructions of existence. Thus the following sentence may have two meanings:

  • སློབ་གྲྭ་ལ་དེབ་འདུག “There are books at the school.” Or, “The school has books.”

Note: Be careful not to confuse this construction with the genitive:

སློབ་གྲྭའི་དེབ་འདུག “There are (some of) the school’s books.”
